content.title: Catheter-Directed Thrombolysis (CDT)
content.definition: Endovascular delivery of fibrinolytic agents directly into thrombus via catheter to achieve targeted clot dissolution. Used for acute arterial occlusion, iliofemoral DVT, and pulmonary embolism. More effective and safer than systemic thrombolysis.

key_concepts.description: Fibrinolytic agents (tPA, urokinase, reteplase) convert plasminogen to plasmin, which degrades fibrin. Direct infusion into thrombus increases local concentration and efficacy
tPA (Alteplase) 0.5-2 mg/hr; Reteplase; Tenecteplase. Urokinase largely unavailable. tPA is most commonly used; half-life ~4-5 minutes
Catheter embedded in thrombus via ipsilateral or contralateral access; multi-sidehole catheter (Cragg-McNamara, Unifuse) for infusion; check with repeat angiography every 4-12 hours
Acute limb ischemia (Rutherford Class I-IIa with viable limb); graft occlusion; native vessel thrombosis; often used when surgical risk is high or anatomy unfavorable for open surgery
Iliofemoral DVT (ATTRACT trial showed reduced PTS but no mortality benefit); catheter-directed > systemic for iliofemoral; consider in young, active patients with low bleeding risk
Recent major surgery (<10 days), recent stroke (<3 months), active bleeding, uncontrolled hypertension, pregnancy, bacterial endocarditis. Irreversible ischemia (Rutherford Class III)
Fibrinogen levels (stop if <100 mg/dL); PTT; hemoglobin; clinical limb assessment; check angiography every 4-12 hours; typical treatment duration 12-48 hours
Combining CDT with mechanical thrombectomy devices (AngioJet, EKOS ultrasound); reduces lytic dose and treatment time; EKOS uses ultrasound to enhance drug penetration
Bleeding (major bleeding 5-10%); intracranial hemorrhage (0.5-1%); compartment syndrome; distal embolization; access site hematoma; allergic reaction (rare)
Address underlying lesion (PTA, stent, bypass); anticoagulation; surveillance; treat cause of thrombosis (hypercoagulable workup if unprovoked)

learning_objectives: Understand catheter-directed thrombolysis technique and agents
Identify indications for CDT in arterial and venous disease
clinical_pearls: CDT works best with fresh thrombus (<14 days)
Stop lysis if fibrinogen drops below 100 mg/dL
ATTRACT trial: CDT for DVT reduces PTS but doesn't affect mortality
Rutherford Class IIb = consider embolectomy over lysis (too threatened)
Always address underlying lesion after successful lysis
Pharmacomechanical reduces treatment time and lytic dose
common_mistakes: Using CDT for irreversible ischemia (Class III)
Expecting lysis alone without treating underlying lesion
